summary: So, given Maisie says Arya ends the series alone, and in season 6 Arya asked “What is west of Westeros?” I am pretty sure this...
body:
So, given Maisie says Arya ends the series alone, and in season 6 Arya asked “What is west of Westeros?” I am pretty sure this is how her story will end.

Arya announces her intention to sail across the Sunset Sea, assuring that she will be back someday. She has happy-tender goodbyes with her family and Gendry (in the show they will probably kiss, in the book there might be some light flirting). While she is sailing away, however, we linger on a shot of her looking rather sad. Or its reversed with sad-tender goodbyes and a shot of her looking excited for her next adventure. Either way, it will be ambiguous and people will be asking, “But does she come back?” until the end of time.

Either way, it will be ambiguous and people will be asking, “But does she come back?” until the end of time.

blog.name: gendrie
blog.title: fierce and terrible and hers
blog.description:
annalesa / 27 / pisces /
they would not make her yield

title: arya/gendry + ice and fire
body:
NORTH / SOUTH

“You are Arya of Winterfell, daughter of the north. You told me you could be strong. You have the wolf blood in you.”

“You have black hair and blue eyes, and you were born in the shadow of the Red Keep. Has no one ever remarked upon your face?”

OLD GODS / R’HLLOR

The old gods of the north must have been guiding her steps.

“Is there some other god he loves?” asked Hyle Hunt. / “The Lord of Light,”

STRENGTH AND SPEED

“You don’t know how strong I am.”
“You don’t know how quick I am.”

LUNAR ANIMAL / SOLAR ANIMAL

And dreamed. That was the best part, the dreaming. She dreamed of wolves most every night.

“A smart boy, but stubborn. That helm … the others call him bullheaded, so he threw it in their teeth." 

SMOL AND TOL

She felt so tiny in his arms, nothing but a scrawny little girl.

The master called over a tall lad about Robb’s age, his arms and chest corded with muscle.

OFFENSIVE WEAPON / DEFENSIVE ARMOR 

Sleep did not come easy, so she borrowed Yoren’s stone and set to honing Needle.

Then he’d go off to polish his helm. It was a beautiful helm, rounded and curved, with a slit visor and two great metal bull’s horns. 

GIRL / BOY

 ”I’m a girl,“ Arya said, exasperated.

"You’re the eunuch.” / “You know I’m not.” Gendry smiled. “You want me to take out my cock and prove it? I don’t have anything to hide.”

HIGHBORN / LOWBORN

“You play at being a servant, but in your heart you are a lord’s daughter. You have taken other names, but you wore them as lightly as you might wear a gown. Under them was always Arya.”

“That’s right,” he said angrily. “I’m too bloody lowborn to be kin to m'lady high.”

blog.name: first-of-her-nxme
blog.title: I see you, wolf child. Blood child

summary: Hello, please explain how does Jaqen know that Arya is a Stark “Some men have many names. Weasel. Arry. Arya.”
question: Hello, please explain how does Jaqen know that Arya is a Stark “Some men have many names. Weasel. Arry. Arya.”
answer:
Hello :)

He has reasons to know who she is :

- he was released from the black cells thanks to Ned Stark and Varys, so he knows who Ned was and probably heard about his daughters

- while in the black cells Varys visited Ned to tell him what was going on with his family and what Cersei wanted to do with him, he could as well visit Jaqen, also  Jaqen could have heard them talking

- Arya used to chase cats around the Red Keep, she even ended in the cellars once, thanks to his blind training Jaqen could have heard her “she steals in on little mice feet, but a man hears”

- Ned was supposed to be sent to the Wall, Yoren and his recruits were waiting for him, instead of Ned Arya joined them at the last moment

- while on the road Arya beat up Hot Pie for an attempt of stealing her sword, she took a water dancer stance before attacking him, children of commoners didn’t get sword training

- in Harrenhal only Arya sneaks into the godswood to pray under the weirwood tree

- she’s dressed as a boy but she never bathes with the other boys, she never takes her clothes off when someone may see her, that’s how Gendry guessed she was a girl

- Arya is too pretty to be a boy, at the beginning of the story we see her mostly through Catelyn and Sansa POV and Arya herself is so insecure about her looks she doesn’t believe she could be pretty even though Ned told her she looked like her beautiful aunt Lyanna, Jaqen and Gendry weren’t the only ones to notice, Roose Bolton knew she was a girl the moment he saw her

This particular line you mentioned shows how characters in asoiaf create their false identities. Weasel is an orphaned girl Arya has met, Arry is a version of her own name and it leads to Arya. There is always a bit of truth in every false identity, it could be a name of someone you love, a place you know, a story you’ve heard or even your own name spelled backwards ( Alleras ). We see the same pattern in Sansa’s Alayne, Tyrion’s Hugor and others. George Martin provide us with all these clues to help us guess Jaqen’s true story. I also think Jaqen mocks Arya a little, pointing out she has to try harder because it’s not hard to guess Arya from Arry.    

Thank you for the ask :)

tags: the stag the wolf and the icehouse
summary: hey so i just came across ur blog and do you ship them in a sibling/platonic way??? i’m just curious cus i thought ur last lil...
question: hey so i just came across ur blog and do you ship them in a sibling/platonic way??? i’m just curious cus i thought ur last lil mini imagine about the fort was cute & that’s how i saw it
answer:
I want to start off with saying that I havent read the books yet and I know in the books there’s much more Arya x Gendry. I definitely ship them romantically. But I can also see how you can get the surrogate sibling relationship from their chemistry as well.


I have a surrogate big brother thats 4 years older than me and he teases me the same way Gendry does Arya worse even so I totally see where you are coming from.

blog.name: jackoshadows
blog.title: Jak O' the Shadows
blog.description: I’m not going to swear an oath I can’t uphold. Talk about my father if you want. Tell me that’s the attitude that got him killed. But when enough people make false promises, words stop meaning anything. Then there are no more answers - only better and better lies. And lies won’t help us in this fight - Jon Snow.

summary: While I do agree that D&D really don’t know how to do well written strong female characters on the show - or any character for...
body:
While I do agree that D&D really don’t know how to do well written strong female characters on the show - or any character for that matter considering how Jon has been stripped of his complexities on the show, I disagree with the idea that it’s just been the male characters that have been white washed on the show. The female characters on the show have been liberally white-washed as well in their transition from books to show. Consider:

Sansa Stark: Her defining act in book one is the betrayal of her family to Cersei. her tattling to Cersei all of Ned’s plans leads to Arya, Jeyne and Sansa herself not being on a ship to WF as Ned intended. Instead Jeyne gets stuck with LF, Arya has to go on the run and Sansa herself is stuck in KL. Ned confesses to save Sansa’s life and ends up losing his head. GRRM has said that Sansa is partially responsible for Ned’s death. And yet on the show, Sansa does not tattle to Cersei, the show blames Ned for everything that happened in KL with Sansa calling him stupid and Arya has no real issues with Sansa and has to fight with her over a letter. Even in the Vale, Sansa has no issues giving SweetRobin dangerously high levels of SweetSleep because LF knows best. Even on the show D&D never fully commit to Sansa’s arc of choosing between power and family, often framing scenes as Jon and Arya being in the wrong while Sansa is right to go against them. D&D have admitted that they don’t like it when Sansa gets hate from an audience and Bryan Cogman’s hyper-defensiveness of the character is an indication of why the writing for Sansa is so bad on the show.

Catelyn Stark: Catelyn in the books really dislikes Jon Snow. And that’s fine, that’s a flaw in this very well written unique strong female character in the books. But the one thing that really made book readers dislike her was this bit:

“It should have been you”

Catelyn wishing that it was Jon who was dying instead of Bran. Cruel and vicious. Catelyn calling Jon by his name for the first time - only to tell him that she wished he was the one dying. Jon feeling scared and nervous about entering the room when Cat was there. Jon hiding his sadness from Robb etc. Cat embraced her dislike of Jon and while she sometimes felt slightly guilty about it (Like when she met Mya), she never shied away from it. The show on the other hand, removed this whole part and added a whole scene about Cat feeling sad because she could not love Jon as a son.

Cersei Lannister: Cersei of one of those rare characters who is actually much well written on the show compared to the books. She’s not one dimensionally evil like the book version and Lena Headey adds weight to the character with her wonderful acting. While GRRM throws Cersei’s character under the bus for Jaime’s redemption arc, the show does the opposite and develops Cersei at Jaime’s expense. In the books, it’s Cersei who kills all of Robert’s bastard babies. On the show it’s Joffrey.

Daenerys Targaryen: With respect to Arya and Dany, D&D’s take on them reduces them to merciless, bad-ass killers stripping them of their complexities, guilt, remorse, self-doubt, and regret which in the books makes us understand why these characters do the things they do. While the show has added in some shitty scenes (Dany roasting the slavers), they have also removed some parts that are often used to critique Dany’s rule in slaver’s bay. These include:

- her impulsive decision to have the wineseller’s daughters interrogated by the shavepate when her beloved unsullied are ambushed and murdered. Dany does regret this later, but this is one of her unpopular actions.

- the collective punishment she hands out in which innocent people including children may have died.

- I also like that on the show Dany executes Mossador for murder while in the books, she hesitates to punish her men for the crimes they commit against the former slavers.

Arya Stark: Arya is such a beautifully written character in the books - a fun loving child who becomes a traumatized child soldier after her harrowing trip through Westeros and ending up in Braavos. D&D reading her as just a bad-ass ninja going from one fun adventure to another clearly shows in how they write her as a revenge obsessed psychopath who is only good at killing.

In the books, Arya does end up killing the insurance man. She mulls over it for an entire chapter trying to convince herself that this was the right thing to do - but she feels guilt and feels like she has no other choice. But she does do it. On the show, Arya is sidetracked by Meryn Trant and kills him instead. And then the FM gives her Lady Crane and she decides to not do it and leaves the FM.

So, I would say that all the characters on the show have been whitewashed and not just the male characters. Some of Jon’s morally complex decisions have been removed on the show - but that’s not surprising considering his entire arc in ADwD was removed in favor of highlighting how Sansa is now a political mastermind and bad-ass who takes down Ramsay.

In my opinion, Tyrion is the most white-washed character on the show. That’s why I find it rather hilarious when he criticizes Dany - this is the guy who burned people to death using wildfire, the guy who rapes a slave out of bitterness - he is now the moral beacon of the show? GRRM is probably laughing right now at that thought!!

reblog.comment:
While I do agree that D&D really don’t know how to do well written strong female characters on the show - or any character for that matter considering how Jon has been stripped of his complexities on the show, I disagree with the idea that it’s just been the male characters that have been white washed on the show. The female characters on the show have been liberally white-washed as well in their transition from books to show. Consider:

Sansa Stark: Her defining act in book one is the betrayal of her family to Cersei. her tattling to Cersei all of Ned’s plans leads to Arya, Jeyne and Sansa herself not being on a ship to WF as Ned intended. Instead Jeyne gets stuck with LF, Arya has to go on the run and Sansa herself is stuck in KL. Ned confesses to save Sansa’s life and ends up losing his head. GRRM has said that Sansa is partially responsible for Ned’s death. And yet on the show, Sansa does not tattle to Cersei, the show blames Ned for everything that happened in KL with Sansa calling him stupid and Arya has no real issues with Sansa and has to fight with her over a letter. Even in the Vale, Sansa has no issues giving SweetRobin dangerously high levels of SweetSleep because LF knows best. Even on the show D&D never fully commit to Sansa’s arc of choosing between power and family, often framing scenes as Jon and Arya being in the wrong while Sansa is right to go against them. D&D have admitted that they don’t like it when Sansa gets hate from an audience and Bryan Cogman’s hyper-defensiveness of the character is an indication of why the writing for Sansa is so bad on the show.

Catelyn Stark: Catelyn in the books really dislikes Jon Snow. And that’s fine, that’s a flaw in this very well written unique strong female character in the books. But the one thing that really made book readers dislike her was this bit:

“It should have been you”

Catelyn wishing that it was Jon who was dying instead of Bran. Cruel and vicious. Catelyn calling Jon by his name for the first time - only to tell him that she wished he was the one dying. Jon feeling scared and nervous about entering the room when Cat was there. Jon hiding his sadness from Robb etc. Cat embraced her dislike of Jon and while she sometimes felt slightly guilty about it (Like when she met Mya), she never shied away from it. The show on the other hand, removed this whole part and added a whole scene about Cat feeling sad because she could not love Jon as a son.

Cersei Lannister: Cersei of one of those rare characters who is actually much well written on the show compared to the books. She’s not one dimensionally evil like the book version and Lena Headey adds weight to the character with her wonderful acting. While GRRM throws Cersei’s character under the bus for Jaime’s redemption arc, the show does the opposite and develops Cersei at Jaime’s expense. In the books, it’s Cersei who kills all of Robert’s bastard babies. On the show it’s Joffrey.

Daenerys Targaryen: With respect to Arya and Dany, D&D’s take on them reduces them to merciless, bad-ass killers stripping them of their complexities, guilt, remorse, self-doubt, and regret which in the books makes us understand why these characters do the things they do. While the show has added in some shitty scenes (Dany roasting the slavers), they have also removed some parts that are often used to critique Dany’s rule in slaver’s bay. These include:

- her impulsive decision to have the wineseller’s daughters interrogated by the shavepate when her beloved unsullied are ambushed and murdered. Dany does regret this later, but this is one of her unpopular actions.

- the collective punishment she hands out in which innocent people including children may have died.

- I also like that on the show Dany executes Mossador for murder while in the books, she hesitates to punish her men for the crimes they commit against the former slavers.

Arya Stark: Arya is such a beautifully written character in the books - a fun loving child who becomes a traumatized child soldier after her harrowing trip through Westeros and ending up in Braavos. D&D reading her as just a bad-ass ninja going from one fun adventure to another clearly shows in how they write her as a revenge obsessed psychopath who is only good at killing.

In the books, Arya does end up killing the insurance man. She mulls over it for an entire chapter trying to convince herself that this was the right thing to do - but she feels guilt and feels like she has no other choice. But she does do it. On the show, Arya is sidetracked by Meryn Trant and kills him instead. And then the FM gives her Lady Crane and she decides to not do it and leaves the FM.

So, I would say that all the characters on the show have been whitewashed and not just the male characters. Some of Jon’s morally complex decisions have been removed on the show - but that’s not surprising considering his entire arc in ADwD was removed in favor of highlighting how Sansa is now a political mastermind and bad-ass who takes down Ramsay.

In my opinion, Tyrion is the most white-washed character on the show. That’s why I find it rather hilarious when he criticizes Dany - this is the guy who burned people to death using wildfire, the guy who rapes a slave out of bitterness - he is now the moral beacon of the show? GRRM is probably laughing right now at that thought!!

blog.name: tatticstudio55

summary: The knight who laughed at the tree
title: The knight who laughed at the tree
body:
(Pic source in the comment section, because apparently there’s a problem with tumblr and links lately…)

OR: Lyanna/Rhaegar elements in the Arya/Gendry storyline

The matter of disguise is important in both storylines, especially at the beginning, when Gendry’s identity is solely defined by his bull helm (he’s simply called “the Bull”). Like the peculiar knight of the laughing tree, his whereabout must be kept secret. Lyanna is the laughing tree to Gendry’s bull: they’re both their armors. Arya herself is a hidden princess, and a reluctantly betrothed one at that (poor, poor Elmar Frey…), garbed in ill-fitting gears: she lost her Needle and the sword Gendry stole for her is simply too big for Arya’s size, mirroring Lyanna’s mismatched, patched up armor at Harrenhal.

Through the first Arya POV chapters of ASOS, we’re introduced to Tom Sevenstrings, who gets all the girls from the Riverland with his harp, and Harwin, who compares Arya to Lyanna when the former attempts to flee on horseback:

Both horses were lathered and flagging by the time he came up beside her, reached over, and grabbed her bridle. Arya was breathing hard herself then. She knew the fight was done. “You ride like a northman, milady,” Harwin said when he’d drawn them to a halt. “Your aunt was the same. Lady Lyanna. But my father was master of horse, remember.” – Arya, ASOS

But the juicy parts happen at lady Smallwood’s keep, when Arya is shoved into a green acorn dress and brown socking – she’s, quite literally, turned into a tree (Gendry even calls her a “nice oak tree”, how romantic, huh?), which M. Bull himself finds exquisitely funny…

Supper was being served in the hall by the time Arya was all washed and combed and dressed. Gendry took one look and laughed so hard that wine came out his nose, until Harwin gave him a thwack alongside his ear. – Arya, ASOS

They do some mildly suggestive wrestling on a smithy’s floor, and when they get back, Tom Sevenstrings is signing a song about a lady in a gown of leaves:

And how she smiled and how she laughed,

the maiden of the tree.

She spun away and said to him, no featherbed for me.

I’ll wear a gown of golden leaves,

and bind my hair with grass,

But you can be my forest love,

and me your forest lass. (Arya, ASOS)

(And then lady Smallwood regrets that she’s got no gown of leaves for Arya, to replace the acorn dress that got torn.)

blog.name: agirlhasnoregrets

blog.description:
A girl has no regrets.

A girl is no one.

blog.description:
Im a proud black woman. Brooklyn Nine-Nine, Peaky Blinders, Animal Kingdom, Game of Thrones and Queen Beyonce.

I write Isaiah Jesus

I do Headcanons. Inbox open.

Spoiler Free Zone!

MASTERLIST

tags: the stag the wolf and the icehouse
but you better credit me for the idea
body:
Gendrya Modern AU idea

So we know Gendry had no family. So that means he probably grew up and never made a pillow fort. 😔

So Imagine it coming up in conversation and Arya is like, nope. We definitely gotta do this one day. And they make a pillow fort in the middle of their room.

title: The Village
description:
by ann_and_white_elephant

Different world, different time, Jon and Arya still meet.

Words: 15001, Chapters: 1/1, Language: English

  • Fandoms: A Song of Ice and Fire - George R. R. Martin
  • Rating: Mature
  • Warnings: Graphic Depictions Of Violence
  • Categories: F/M
  • Characters: Arya Stark, Jon Snow, Gendry Waters, Sansa Stark, Viserys Targaryen, Roose Bolton
  • Relationships: Jon Snow/Arya Stark, Arya Stark/Gendry Waters (Past), Arya Stark & Sansa Stark
  • Additional Tags: Alternate Universe - Historical, Bronze Age, Valyria, Arranged Marriage, Mildly Dubious Consent
